metadata.title: NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES
metadata.author: Honghua Dong, Jiayuan Mao, Tian Lin, Chong Wang, Lihong Li, and Denny Zhou, 1 ITCS, IIIS, Tsinghua University {dhh, mjy,}@mails.tsinghua.edu.cn 2 Google Inc. {tianlin,lihong,dennyzhou}@google.com 3 ByteDance Inc. chong.wang@bytedance.com
metadata.abstract: We propose the Neural Logic Machine (NLM), a neural-symbolic architecture for both inductive learning and logic reasoning. NLMs exploit the power of both neural networks—as function approximators, and logic programming—as a symbolic processor for objects with properties, relations, logic connectives, and quantifiers. After being trained on small-scale tasks (such as sorting short arrays), NLMs can recover lifted rules, and generalize to large-scale tasks (such as sorting longer arrays). In our experiments, NLMs achieve perfect generalization in a number of tasks, from relational reasoning tasks on the family tree and general graphs, to decision making tasks including sorting arrays, finding shortest paths, and playing the blocks world. Most of these tasks are hard to accomplish for neural networks or inductive logic programming alone. 1

highlights: Deep learning has achieved great success in various applications such as speech recognition (Hinton et al, 2012), image classification (Krizhevsky et al, 2012; He et al, 2016), machine translation (Sutskever et al, 2014; Bahdanau et al, 2015; Wu et al, 2016; Vaswani et al, 2017), and game playing (Mnih et al, 2015; Silver et al, 2017)
We propose Neural Logic Machines (NLMs) to address the aforementioned challenges
In Section 3 we evaluate the effectiveness of NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES on a broad set of tasks ranging from relational reasoning to decision making
We propose a novel neural-symbolic architecture called Neural Logic Machines (NLMs) which can conduct first-order logic deduction
The maximum depth of the NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES is a hyperparameter to be specified for individual problems
Unlike Inductive logic programming methods that learn a set of rules in an explainable format, the learned rules of NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES are implicitly encoded as weights of the neural networks
key_statements: Deep learning has achieved great success in various applications such as speech recognition (Hinton et al, 2012), image classification (Krizhevsky et al, 2012; He et al, 2016), machine translation (Sutskever et al, 2014; Bahdanau et al, 2015; Wu et al, 2016; Vaswani et al, 2017), and game playing (Mnih et al, 2015; Silver et al, 2017)
We propose Neural Logic Machines (NLMs) to address the aforementioned challenges
In Section 3 we evaluate the effectiveness of NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES on a broad set of tasks ranging from relational reasoning to decision making
We further show that NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES can efficiently realize a partial set of Horn clauses
We show that NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES trained using small-sized instances can generalize to large-sized instances

While NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES can scale up to complex rules, the number of objects/entities or relations should be bounded as a small value (e.g., < 1000), since all predicates are represented as tensors
We propose a novel neural-symbolic architecture called Neural Logic Machines (NLMs) which can conduct first-order logic deduction
Empirical evaluations show that our method is able to learn the underlying logical rules from small-scale tasks, and generalize to large-scale tasks
The maximum depth of the NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES is a hyperparameter to be specified for individual problems
Unlike Inductive logic programming methods that learn a set of rules in an explainable format, the learned rules of NEURAL LOGIC MACHINES are implicitly encoded as weights of the neural networks
summary: Deep learning has achieved great success in various applications such as speech recognition (Hinton et al, 2012), image classification (Krizhevsky et al, 2012; He et al, 2016), machine translation (Sutskever et al, 2014; Bahdanau et al, 2015; Wu et al, 2016; Vaswani et al, 2017), and game playing (Mnih et al, 2015; Silver et al, 2017).
Given a set of base predicates, grounded on a set of objects, NLMs sequentially apply first-order rules to draw conclusions, such as a property about an object.
We present different modules of our neural operators by making analogies to a set of essential meta-rules in symbolic logic systems.
Our neural implementation of boolean logic rules is a lifted neural module that uniformly applies to any grounding entries (x1 · · · xr) in the output tensor pU .
The expansion meta-rule (Eq 3) for a set of C r-ary predicates, represented by a [mr, C]-shaped tensor, introduces a new and distinct variable xr+1.
The reduction meta-rule (Eq 4) for a set of C (r + 1)-ary predicates, represented by a [mr+1, C]shaped tensor, eliminates the variable xr+1 via quantifiers.

For each object pair (x, y), the output U -grounding tensor of predicates is computed by intra-group computation Oi(2)(x, y) = MLP(Concat(Ii(2)(x, y), Ii(2)(y, x)); θi(2)), and the output shape is [m, m − 1, Ci(2)].
Given the training dataset containing pairs of, NLMs can induce lifted rules that entail the conclusions and generalize w.r.t. the number of objects during testing.

For ∂ILP, we take the grounded probability of the “target” predicate as the output; for an NLM with D layers, we take the corresponding group of output predicates at the last layer to represent unary predicates, while for relation prediction we use tensor OD(2) to represent binary predicates) and classify the property or relation with a linear layer.
For both MemNN and NLM, we apply a shared MLP on the output relational predicates of each pair of objects OD(2)(x, y) and compute an action score s(x, y).
Our method can deal with more complex tasks such as the blocks world which requires using a large number of intermediate predicates, while ∂ILP fails to search in such a large space.
NLMs are general neural architectures for learning lifted rules from only input-output pairs.
While NLMs can scale up to complex rules, the number of objects/entities or relations should be bounded as a small value (e.g., < 1000), since all predicates are represented as tensors.
This work removes such restrictions and introduces a neural architecture to capture lifted rules defined on any set of objects.
The goal of our paper is to introduce a neural architecture which learns lifted rules and handle relational data with multiple orders.
Extracting human-readable rules from NLMs would be a meaningful future direction
headline: We propose the Neural Logic Machine, a neural-symbolic architecture for both inductive learning and logic reasoning
